_header: Sith all that in this world hath been in rerum natura
Note:
English and Latin alternate lines; for another version of a portion of this, see 6469; see Walther (1963)
XWalther, Hans. Proverbia sententiaque latinitatis medii aevi. 6 vols. Göttingen, 1963-69, no. 8036.
_description: ‘Esto memor mortis’ — eighty-four macaronic lines in 12-line stanzas (ababababcdcd)

BodDou126.First Lines:
Al þat haþ ben or ys in rerum naturaOr in þis
                    world haþ ben sen in hamana cura…
BodDou126.Last Lines:
…Te ponet in tumilum tyl domys day to dwelleHoc
                        relinquis seculum þer ys nat ellys to telle

CULEe629.First Lines:
Syth alle þat in þys wordle haþ beenin rerum
                        naturaOr in þys wyde wordle was seenin humana
                    cura…
CULEe629.Last Lines:
…Be redy þere for y warne þeDe te peccata
                        fugando
CULEe629.Attributed Title:
Esto memor mortis iam porta sit amnibus ortis / Sepe sibi iuuenes
                        accipit ante sones (f. 21)
CULEe629.Editions:
Wright,  Thomas,  and  James Orchard Halliwell-Phillipps, eds.  
             Reliquiae Antiquae.
         2 vols. London: Smith, 1845: 1.138-9.
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.  
             Religious Lyrics of the XIV Century.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1924. 2nd ed., rev.: G. V. Smithers, Oxford,
            1952: 239-40.
Stevick,  Robert D.,
                        ed.  
             One Hundred Middle English Lyrics.
         Indianapolis: Bobbs-Merrill, 1964: 81-3.

CamTCC365.First Lines:
Sen al þat is or wasIn rerum naturaOr in þis
                    wilde warlde was seyn In humana curaAll sall wende wit owtyn
                    wene via mortis duraGod leue þat man sall be dene
                        penas non passura…
CamTCC365.Last Lines:
…Dulful dede drede wew
vemet quia nescio quodBe redy to dede I redePeccata
                        fugando
CamTCC365.Attributed Title:
Esto memor mortis nam porta sit omnibus ortis / Sepe sibi Iuuenes mors
                        rapit autem senes (f. 195v); Explicit memoraccio bona
                    (f. 196)

BLAdd60577.First Lines:
When thou leste wenythe
veniet mors te superareThus thy grave grenetheErgo mortis
                        memorare…
BLAdd60577.Last Lines:
…Doolefull deed drede Iveniet mors nescio
                    quandoTherefore be redye rede Ide te peccata
                    fugando
BLAdd60577.Note:
Missing first four lines and Latin epigraph; written with Latin and
                    English together on each line (i.e., one line in MS for two lines as written
                    here); these first lines same as 6469.
BLAdd60577.Editions:
Wilson,  Edward. 
             “Introduction.” 
             The Winchester Anthology. A Facsimile of British Library Additional
                Manuscript 60577. With an account of the music by 
                    Iain
                    Fenlon. 
         Cambridge: D. S. Brewer, 1981.

BLCottCleoDVI.Transcription:
Sithen all that is and hathe bene in rerum naturaAll shall wynde
                    withoutyn wene via mortis duraGod leaue manne folle be cleane penas non
                    passura

BLHar3362.First Lines: Seþene all þat is or haþ ben in rerum naturaOr in þys wylde worlde was sene in humana cura…
BLHar3362.Last Lines: …Te ponet in tumulum tyl domys day to dwellehoc relinque seculum þer ys nouȝt ellys to telle
BLHar3362.Note: Eighteen lines only in this witness; preceded by Latin couplet, “Esto memor mortis….”
